name: Style
comment: An enum type describing a "flavor" of path.

platform.name: platform
platform.comment:
The style of the host platform.

When running on the command line, this will be path/path.Style.windows or path/path.Style.posix based on the host operating system. On a browser, this will be path/path.Style.url.

posix.name: posix
posix.comment: POSIX-style paths use "/" (forward slash) as separators. Absolute paths start with "/". Used by UNIX, Linux, Mac OS X, and others.

relativeRootPattern.name: relativeRootPattern
relativeRootPattern.comment:
The dart-core.Pattern that can be used to match the root prefix of a root-relative path in this style.

This can be null to indicate that this style doesn't support root-relative paths.

url.name: url
url.comment:
URLs aren't filesystem paths, but they're supported to make it easier to manipulate URL paths in the browser.

URLs use "/" (forward slash) as separators. Absolute paths either start with a protocol and optional hostname (e.g. http://dartlang.org, file://) or with "/".

windows.name: windows
windows.comment: Windows paths use "\" (backslash) as separators. Absolute paths start with a drive letter followed by a colon (example, "C:") or two backslashes ("\\") for UNC paths.

name.name: name
name.comment: The name of this path style. Will be "posix" or "windows".

needsSeparatorPattern.name: needsSeparatorPattern
needsSeparatorPattern.comment:
The dart-core.Pattern that matches path components that need a separator after them.

Windows and POSIX styles just need separators when the previous component doesn't already end in a separator, but the URL always needs to place a separator between the root and the first component, even if the root already ends in a separator character. For example, to join "file://" and "usr", an additional "/" is needed (making "file:///usr").

rootPattern.name: rootPattern
rootPattern.comment: The dart-core.Pattern that can be used to match the root prefix of an absolute path in this style.

separator.name: separator
separator.comment: The path separator for this style. On POSIX, this is /. On Windows, it's \.

separatorPattern.name: separatorPattern
separatorPattern.comment: The dart-core.Pattern that can be used to match a separator for a path in this style. Windows allows both "/" and "\" as path separators even though "\" is the canonical one.

absolutePathToUri.name: absolutePathToUri
absolutePathToUri.comment: Returns the URI that represents path/path.Style.absolutePathToUri.path, which is assumed to be absolute.

getRelativeRoot.name: getRelativeRoot
getRelativeRoot.comment:
Gets the root prefix of path/path.Style.getRelativeRoot.path if it's root-relative.

If path/path.Style.getRelativeRoot.path is relative or absolute and not root-relative, returns null.

getRoot.name: getRoot
getRoot.comment: Gets the root prefix of path/path.Style.getRoot.path if path is absolute. If path/path.Style.getRoot.path is relative, returns null.

pathFromUri.name: pathFromUri
pathFromUri.comment: Returns the path represented by path/path.Style.pathFromUri.uri in this style.

relativePathToUri.name: relativePathToUri
relativePathToUri.comment: Returns the URI that represents the relative path made of parts.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides path/path.Style.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and path/path.Style.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the path/path.Style.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
path/path.Style.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to path/path.Style.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If path/path.Style.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of path/path.Style.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
